intro: Cordylocarpus muricatus var. trichocarpus, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the Asparagaceae family and is characterized by its fibrous, strap-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in inflorescences. It is often found in coastal and lowland areas, thriving in moist, well-drained soils. The fibrous material from its leaves has historically been used by Māori for weaving and other traditional purposes.
